Comment: Fischer was known for his active style of play. He proved that the concept of universallism: in essence, this means being strong and having the ability to connect positional and tactical play was needed to be most successful in this game. Being such an active player, he preferred active, not passive moves.

?! - Here Fischer adopts a line not a lot of players use with today's theory. Even in his day, this move at first look makes little sense at first glance. I mean, choosing to push a pawn instead of continuing to develop the bishops? Seems like an amateur mistake to me. But never underestimate the mind of a genius such as Fischer. Think smarter, not harder. What could Fischer possibly be planning?

Black, naturally continues his development, undeterred and unwary about what is going on in the mind of Fischer.
?! - Starting to understand yet why Fischer is willing to sacrifice his development? He is trying to gain space on the board, a positional concept!

!? - Black is trying to prove white wrong. He is saying if you are going to delay your development and gain space, then I will just play fast and exploit it. Here is a question I pose to you reader: how do you know if the beginning of an attack is just right or too soon? Perhaps you need to consider 2 factors: preparation, and follow up. Why am I mentioning 2 obvious things here and now? Well, let's look and see: black started advancing and attacking, but overlooked a very important detail: the follow-up! It's a mistake you often see in games at the 2000+ level, where positional chess becomes more of a deciding factor in games. But now you see why this attack failed.

! - A great response. Now that white has the initiative, time to apply some pressure of his own. Force that knight to move, delay the castle, but most importantly, drive the opponent away.

So now that the opening phase is now complete (both sides are now castled), let's analyze the positions. I really like white's space acquired on the board, the control he has, and all the possibilities he has. Trouble may come when it comes to carrying out an attack as black can defend quite well, but never underestimate the mind of a genius. Or as my mother puts it, "Where there is a will, there is a way."

Fischer remembers another edict of positional play: you are not just considering your own moves, you are also thinking about your opponent's responses. As white can ill-afford to have an attack on the centre, he adds another defender to his centre pawn (notice this isn't a piece defending it, it is another pawn!).

What is Fischer doing now? Why is his attack so slow if his position is so good? He's a zen master as I said before, he's biding his time, weakening black's position even more. A problem that lower rated players have is that they rush the play and don't consider the build up. They do not consider the beauty of the build up. People like me on the other hand, I was raised in an environment of chess. Tactics were nice, but if the position was bad, all the tactics in the world would do nothing to restore it. Just like times of war, you have to have strategies to destroy an enemy, not a strategy, but strategies in case one fails.

! - The secret to success in many plans in chess is to open as many lines for your pieces to use. (Another positional trick) Fischer is just opening the flood gates at this point.

!! - Black is in serious trouble. He cannot take the queen or the game is over. And even with the defense, black cannot mount any sort of counter attacks now.

Now that Fischer has the exact position that he wants, the king cannot move anywhere and the other pieces are pretty much stationary, he is taking other minute threats away from his opponent, so they don't become major problems.
